opinion.posture:
Proceeding seeking an opinion of Supreme Court on error of law.
Writ of Error Dismissed.
opinion.syllabus:
1. CRIMINAL LAW — Writs of Error — State — People — Review — Questionof Law — District Attorney. Under C.R.S. 1963, 39-726 (2), writs of error will lie in behalf of the state, or the people, to review decisions of the trial court in any criminal case upon question of law; it is the duty of the district attorney to sue out a writ of error on behalf of the people.
2. Writs of Error — Party — Original Proceeding. Only a party to the original proceeding may sue out a writ of error.
3. Appeal and Error — Purpose — Parties Aggrieved — SubstantialPage 135Grievance. Appeals are not allowed for the mere purpose of delay, or to present purely abstract legal questions, however important or interesting, but to correct errors injuriously affecting the rights of some party to the litigation; only parties substantially aggrieved may appeal.
opinion.posture: Error to the District Court of Arapahoe County, Hon. Robert B.Lee, Judge.
opinion.attorneys:
MARTIN P. MILLER, District Attorney, 18th Judicial District, State of Colorado, DAVID J. HAHN, Chief Deputy, for plaintiff in error.
DAWSON, NAGEL, SHERMAN HOWARD, RAYMOND J. TURNER, for defendant in error.
opinion.opinion_text:
THE record in this case reveals that the parties in the lower court were the People of the State of Colorado vs. Reeder.
[1] There is now sought an opinion from this court on an error of law pursuant to C.R.S. 1963, 39-7-26 (2). The pertinent part of that Statute is "Writs of error shall lie on behalf of thestate, or the people, to review decisions of the trial court in any criminal case upon question of law * * *." (Emphasis supplied.)
The statute further provides that "* * * it shall be the duty of the district attorney * * * to sue out a writ of error on behalf of the people * * *." (Emphasis supplied.)
[2] In Fischer v. Hanna, 21 Colo. 9, 39 Pac. 420, this court held that only a party to the original proceeding may sue out a writ of error. In the case at bar, Martin P. Miller, District Attorney, was not a party to the proceedings below and is not party aggrieved. He cannot, therefore, be a plaintiff in error in this court.Page 136
In Miller v. Clark, 144 Colo. 431, 356 P.2d 965, this court cited with approval Wilson v. Board of Regents, 46 Colo. 100,102 Pac. 1088, in which may be found the following:
"* * * Appeals are not allowed for the mere purpose of delay, or to present purely abstract legal questions, however important or interesting, but to correct errors injuriously affecting the rights of some party to the litigation. Only parties aggrieved may appeal. The word Aggrieved refer to a substantial grievance, the denial to the party of some claim of right, either of property or of person, or the imposition upon him of some burden or obligation. * * *"
The writ of error is accordingly dismissed.
MR. JUSTICE FRANTZ and MR. JUSTICE McWILLIAMS concur.
